data.title: A comprehensive guide to the different types of books
data.meta_description: There are dozens of different book genres! Read our comprehensive guide and learn where the self-publishing opportunity lies.
data.text:
There are dozens of different book genres, from adventure fiction to self-help books. Many books fall into multiple or crossover genres, such as fantasy and science fiction, or crime and mystery novels.

Each type of book or book genre has a different audience, ideal word count, and price point. If youâre thinking about writing genre fiction, itâs a good idea to know the conventions for your chosen genre before you start writing or planning your book.

Hereâs everything you need to know about the different types of books.

What are the different types of books?

Hereâs a rundown of every main book genre, including 19 fiction and 5 non-fiction book types:

Adventure stories

Classics

Crime

Whatâs the most popular book genre?

All readers have different tastes, so itâs tricky to determine which book genre is most popular. However, taking a look at the all-time bestseller list (excluding religious texts) sheds some light on book genre popularity:

With nearly half of these bestsellers falling into the fantasy genre, this is arguably the most popular type of book among readers. This is backed up by the popularity of series like Harry Potter, Lord Of The Rings, and A Song Of Ice And Fire.

Understanding the importance of book genres

Genre is essential information for readers and publishers. It helps readers know at a glance if theyâre interested in reading a book, and helps publishers understand the marketability of a book. Itâs even important for categorising your book when it eventually hits bookshop shelves.

As a writer, you need to understand the different types of books so you can:

Fulfill reader expectations â Each genre comes with specific expectations (for example, mystery books must include a puzzle that needs to be solved). Donât leave readers disappointed by mischaracterising your book.

Write something new â Getting a good grounding of other books in your genre will help you write an original story that doesnât follow the same old tropes.

Get published â Knowing which genre(s) your book falls into will help you sell it to publishers (or readers if youâre self-publishing).

Every book genre, explained

Letâs take a look at each of the major types of books in more depth, with key information for writers looking to explore each genre including bestselling book examples and the average price for each kind of book.

1. Adventure stories

Adventure novels whisk readers off to faraway lands. Unlike fantasy novels, they tend to stay in the real world (although thereâs often a lot of crossover between these genres). Childrenâs novels often fall into the adventure category, since theyâre designed to spark imaginations.

Adventure story bestsellers:

The Little Prince â Antoine de Saint-ExupÃ©ry

2. Classics

Classics encompass a range of book genres, but they always stand the test of time. Classics include centuries-old stories like Homerâs Odyssey, but also more modern novels that have drawn significant acclaim and attention, such as Margaret Atwoodâs The Handmaidâs Tale and George Orwellâs 1984.

Classic fiction bestsellers:

A Tale Of Two Cities â Charles Dickens

Dream Of The Red Chamber â Cao Xueqin

The Catcher in the Rye â JD Salinger

3. Crime

From murder mysteries to true crime stories, crime is an ever popular genre of books. It tells sinister stories of wrongdoing, and the search for justice. This genre can be very lucrative, with many authors becoming household names, such as Agatha Christie, Val McDermid, and Harlan Coben.

Crime bestsellers:

And Then There Were None â Agatha Christie

The Godfather â Mario Puzo

Gone Girl â Gillian Flynn

4. Fairy tales, fables, and folk tales

Folk tales date back to ancient times, with Aesop being perhaps the most famous curator of these short-form stories. Many fairy tales are of unknown origin, but have survived through retellings down the generations. Modern fairy tale writers like Angela Carter put a contemporary spin on traditional tales.

Fairy tale bestsellers:

The Adventures of Pinocchio â Carlo Collodi

Jonathan Livingston Seagull â Richard Bach

âNumber of fairy and folk tale anthologies available on Amazon: 3,000+

Average word count: 30,000 words

5. Fantasy

Fantasy may be the most popular modern book genre. Thanks to series like Harry Potter and Percy Jackson, itâs particularly popular with young adult readers, although more and more fantasy novels are written for adults (George RR Martin, weâre looking at you). These stories take readers on a journey beyond the known world, to places conjured in the authorâs imagination.

Fantasy bestsellers:

Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone â JK Rowling

The Hobbit â JRR Tolkien

The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe â CS Lewis

Number of fantasy books available on Amazon: 60,000+

6. Historical fiction

Authors like Hilary Mantel and Toni Morrison have popularised the historical fiction genre in recent years. These books give readers a glimpse into the past, with many stories set in times of great conflict and change.

Historical fiction bestsellers:

A Tale Of Two Cities â Charles Dickens

Ben-Hur: A Tale of the Christ â Lew Wallace

The Name of the Rose â Umberto Eco

Number of historical fiction books available on Amazon: 70,000+

Average price for a paperback historical fiction book: Â£8.99

7. Horror

People never tire of being terrified â so horror novels remain some of the bestselling books in the world. While the genre has origins in Gothic stories like Mary Shelleyâs Frankenstein, authors like Stephen King and R L Stine have modernised horror for adults and children alike. The genre has also spawned hundreds of popular horror movies based on books.

Horror bestsellers:

Flowers in the Attic â VC Andrews

Rebecca â Daphne Du Maurier

Jaws â Peter Benchley

8. Humour and satire

From dark dystopian satire like A Clockwork Orange to comedic memoirs, the humour genre of books spans a range of titles. Comedy writing is a real art, so this genre can be hard to pull off for new writers â but a funny book is truly unputdownable.

Humour bestsellers:

Animal Farm â George Orwell

Adventures of Huckleberry Finn â Mark Twain

The Good Soldier Å vejk â Jaroslav HaÅ¡ek

9. Literary fiction

Literary fiction is reserved for books that donât slot neatly into more traditional genres, although it can also be used to differentiate from lighter fiction. Most literary fiction books are character-driven rather than plot-driven, so they tend to be more introspective and meandering.

Literary fiction bestsellers:

The Catcher in the Rye â JD Salinger

To Kill a Mockingbird â Harper Lee

War and Peace â Leo Tolstoy

10. Mystery

Mystery is often seen as a subset of the crime genre, but itâs so popular and enduring that it deserves a category of its own. Agatha Christie, master of the whodunit, is the second best selling author in history, after William Shakespeare. Mysteries are full of suspense, and usually keep the reader guessing until the last moment.

Mystery bestsellers:

And Then There Were None â Agatha Christie

The Da Vinci Code â Dan Brown

Angels & Demons â Dan Brown

Number of mystery books available on Amazon: 70,000+

Average word count: 91,000 words

Average price for a paperback mystery novel: Â£8.99

11. Poetry

Poetry is completely different to novels in form, structure, and style. It contains a wealth of genres in itself, from nonsense verse to war poetry. Poetry has fallen somewhat out of favour in modern book sales, though poets like Amanda Gorman and Ocean Vuong are repopularising the form.

Bestselling poets:

William Shakespeare

Alexander Pushkin

Roald Dahl

Number of poetry books available on Amazon: 30,000+

Average word count: No data available

Average price for a paperback poetry collection: Â£10.19

12. Plays

Plays are written to be performed rather than read, but theyâre still seen as a key literary genre. This is largely due to the enduring popularity of Shakespeareâs plays, as well as other theatrical greats like Tennessee Williamsâs A Streetcar Named Desire and Oscar Wildeâs Salome.

Best selling playwrights:

William Shakespeare

Alexander Pushkin

Number of playscript books available on Amazon: 60,000+

Average page count: 90-130 pages

Average price for a paperback playscript: Â£11.36

13. Romance

Everyone enjoys a good love story â which is why romance novels are one of the most popular types of books. Romance authors Barbara Cartland and Danielle Steel are the third and fourth bestselling fiction writers, with more than 2 billion book sales between them. Even non-romance novels often have a romantic arc at their centre, proving that love and relationships are central to many great stories.

Romance bestsellers:

The Bridges of Madison County â Robert James Waller

Love Story â Erich Segal

The Fault in Our Stars â John Green

Average word count: 91,000 words

14. Science fiction

From Stan Lee to Ursula K Le Guin, thereâs no shortage of famous sci-fi writers. The genre has grown in popularity thanks to the boom in science fiction films based on books, such as Dune and 2001: A Space Odyssey. Sci-fi is often combined with fantasy, and there are some similarities between these types of books. But sci-fi books are usually bound by the laws of science as we know them in the real world.

Sci-fi bestsellers:

Nineteen Eighty-Four â George Orwell

Dune â Frank Herbert

The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy â Douglas Adams

15. Short stories and novellas

Short stories are often found in anthologies or collections, which can be by the same or a variety of authors. Like poetry, short stories tend to be less popular with modern readers, though they remain popular with writers.

Short story bestsellers:

James Bond stories â Ian Fleming

Perry Mason stories â Erle Stanley Gardner

Jack Reacher â Lee Child

16. Thrillers

Thrillers are your typical page-turners. Full of action and suspense, thrillers can also often cross genres, particularly with crime and mystery. John Grisham, Stieg Larsson, and Gillian Flynn are some of the most popular thriller authors writing today, with Flynnâs Gone Girl among the top three bestselling books in the genre.

Thriller bestsellers:

The Eagle Has Landed â Jack Higgins

Gone Girl â Gillian Flynn

17. War

War is a formative experience on an individual, national, and international level. Perhaps thatâs why stories of war fascinate readers the world over, and remain such an enduring theme in modern fiction. War stories are often (though not always) a subset of historical fiction.

War bestsellers:

The Eagle Has Landed â Jack Higgins

18. Womenâs fiction

Womenâs fiction describes books that centre on the experiences and actions of female characters. It can be a controversial term â not everyone agrees with generalising fiction on a gendered basis â but itâs a common way for publishers to market these books. So authors should be aware of it as a genre in its own right. Womenâs fiction encompasses books as wide-ranging as Chimamanda Ngozi Adichieâs Americana to Jojo Moyesâs Me Before You.

Womenâs fiction bestsellers:

The Women's Room â Marilyn French

19. Young adult fiction

Despite being targeted at 13-18 year olds, young adult books have sold more than perhaps any other genre in recent years. This is thanks to hugely popular series like Harry Potter, The Hunger Games, and Twilight. YA books often have a secondary genre, too â Harry Potter and Twilight, for example, are fantasy novels, while John Greenâs The Fault In Our Stars is a romance.

YA fiction bestsellers:

Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone â JK Rowling

Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets â JK Rowling

Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban â JK Rowling

20. Autobiography and memoir

Memoirs and autobiographies are popular among self-publishing writers who have incredible life stories to share. Many famous figures also write autobiographies, or hire a ghostwriter to write one on their behalf, giving fans a glimpse into their lives.

Autobiography and memoir bestsellers:

The Diary of Anne Frank â Anne Frank

Autobiography of a Yogi â Paramahansa Yogananda

Wolf Totem â Jiang Rong

21. Biography

There are millions of real-life stories out there just waiting to be told. Unlike autobiographies and memoirs, which the author writes about themselves, biographies tell the story of someone elseâs life. These are often famous people â Irving Stoneâs Lust For Life, for example, is a biographical novel about Vincent Van Gogh â but they can also be people you know, or lesser-known individuals of interest.

Biographical bestsellers:

Lust for Life â Irving Stone

22. Essays

Essays are more academic than other forms of writing. They tend to follow a thesis set by the author, and elaborate on their perspective on a particular topic or theme. Essays can be book-length (such as Chimamanda Ngozi Adichieâs We Should All Be Feminists), or part of an essay collection (such as James Baldwinâs Notes of a Native Son).

Essay collection bestsellers:

The Hite Report â Shere Hite

23. Non-fiction novels

Non-fiction novels blur the line between fiction and reality. While the facts stay intact, the form and style is closer to that of a traditional fiction book. Non-fiction novels use character and other literary devices to tell a true story. Truman Capoteâs In Cold Blood is a classic example of a non-fiction novel.

Non-fiction novel examples:

24. Self-help books

Self-help books are probably the most popular modern non-fiction genre, since they offer the promise of self-improvement and healing. This also tends to make them a little more expensive than other genres. Books like Dale Carnegieâs How To Win Friends and Influence People have become part of the modern self-help canon.

Self-help book bestsellers:

Which book genre should you write?

Most writers naturally gravitate towards writing in a genre they enjoy reading. And while being well-read in a genre is important, itâs also helpful to learn more about the commercial aspects of your chosen type of book. This includes marketability, competition, and price points.

For example, non-fiction novels have fallen out of favour in recent years, but similar categories like historical fiction and autobiography are still very popular. So think about how you want to position your book, and the nuances of your chosen genre.

Learning more about your preferred genre helps you understand the market for your book, which is especially important when it comes to self-publishing your work.

Now you know a little more about your chosen genre, itâs time to plan your new book. Find out how to write a book outline â itâs a failsafe way to plan a book in any genre.
